quote: We also develop a variant that computes a solution in o(nk) and show experimentally that both algorithms outperform previous techniques.
We show that our changes result in a better approximation guarantee than the previous work.
The cost of our algorithm's final ~-mean solution is at most O( C*), where C* is the cost of the optimum k-means solution.
For our empirical result, we will use a very simple approximate nearest-neighbor algorithm based on random projection.
Our approach to selecting k is closer to what's done in practice, and is more likely to yield meaningful results.
For the Census dataset, k = 12 case, for example, the slowest run of our algorithm (20 minutes) and the fastest run of the D&C algorithm (125 minutes) occurred at the same case.
We see that our algorithms are much faster than the D&C algorithm, while having a comparable (and often better) solution quality.
